guide.summary: Port Oficial do Gentoo para IA64 iniciado

li.uri: Port Oficial do Gentoo para IA64 iniciado

section.title: Port Oficial do Gentoo para IA64 iniciado

body.p: No início da semana Daniel Robbins anunciou no gentoo-dev que a HP havia doado um computador Itanium 2 com 2 processadores para o Gentoo e ditou os passos para o plano de portar, consistindo basicamente em fazer o Portage funcionar em um Debian/IA64 e convertê-lo para uma instalação Gentoo nativa, então expandir o suporte a IA64 pela Portage tree. O que ninguém esperava, no entanto, era que alguém aparecesse com um stage1 tarball funcional e patches de ebuilds suficientes para se ter um sistema utilizável. A máquina doada está instalada na LAN do e está rodando agora o port submetido pelo splite, o misterioso bem-feitor. Se você tem experiência com IA64 e quer ajudar em alguma parte, por favor envie um email para Seemant Kulleen com cópia para Daniel Robbins. Este port será rápido provavelmente, pois muitos desenvolvedores estão interessados; confira as próximas edições do JSG para maiores informações sobre o andamento do projeto.

p.b: Não houve anúncios de segurança nessa semana

body.p: Os seguintes bugs de segurança foram postados na última semana:

li.uri: pam: pam_console gives all users full access to serial ports!

body.p: O História de Usuários não será publicado nessa semana. Lembre-se de nos enviar a sua história bizarra, hilária, ou incrível sobre o Gentoo para que ela possa ser publicada aqui!
Adrian Almenar

This week, we are featuring Adrian Almenar (strider). Adrian works primarily with Gentoo's java team, fixing bugs and maintaining the packages in dev-java/*. He particularly focuses on maintaining the JDK packages and java-config, as well as xalan-j, xerces-j, ant, maven and jikes. Gentoo is his first major role as a developer on an open-source project, but he has collaborated on translating materials for Jakarta-Tomcat. The work he is most proud of was commencing the port of java-config to python, a task that was completed by Todd Berman and Jason Mobarak.

Adrian lives and works in Caracas, Venezuela, where the climate encourages his fondness for cold beer. He is employed as a java programmer for a mobile Internet services company, where 90% of the production servers are now Gentoo-based. At night, he is studying Economic Sciences at the Universidad Central de Venezuela, after studying Computer Science for some years. Despite daytime work, night courses, and weekends working on Gentoo, he still manages to spend a little time with his girlfriend, Stella. He also claims to be able to find time to pursue hobbies in Ham radio, electronics and telecommunications as well as the more prosaic pastimes of reading, movies and going out with friends.

Adrian prefers to use XFCE4 as his Window Manager at work, but uses KDE at home for his mother's sake (yes, his mother uses Gentoo). He uses Sylpheed-claws to manage his 5 email accounts, and prefers Mozilla-Firebird, Gaim, XMMS, J-Pilot, GKrellm, vim and kvim for other tools. His home computers are a Pentium IV 1.8 GHz (768 Mb, Geforce 2) development box and an Athlon 800 MHz (128 Mb, TNT2) that serves as a mail server, firewall, and computer for his mother.

Adrian first began using Linux with Slackware in 1996, when he used it for Web development and Java programming in his first job. He became aware of Gentoo in April of 2002, and began using it that June, when the 1.2 release was available. When he discovered how well it met his needs, he began using it at work, and eventually assisted with the migration of many of his company's computers to Gentoo. He offered us a quote from the movie Hackers, which he says describes Linux' role in the OS market: "Mess with the best, die like the rest."

Quando oubipaws despreocupadamente informou que ele estava rodando Gentoo Linux no seu Apple Macintosh G5, a elite de desenvolvedores Gentoo PPC concentraram-se na thread para ver o que estava acontecendo. Infelizmente, os céticos prevaleceram no final, mas ao menos a excitação era real ... E mesmo os desenvolvedores mais espertos estão definitivamente felizes em ver tantas pessoas tentando executar o Gentoo Linux em seus novos G5:

Nem todo mundo procura por apenas quinze minutos de fama ... Melhor do que impulsionar suas personalidades para as fachadas, algumas pessoas obtém sucesso ao usar o Forum como um canal para colocar seus trabalhos no centro das atenções. Com 20.000 usuários regulares e uma agradável audiência, isto é costumeiramente aclamado e impulsionado pelos usuários do Forum. O exemplo mais óbvio desta semana vem do Lovechild. A lenda dos foruns e contribuidor notório do site Breakmygentoo agora tem seu próprio conjunto de patches para o kernel, e na última semana abriu um tópico nos forums que se tornou a segunda casa dos alegres guerrilheiros da performance:

li.uri: Love-sources - pegue-os antes que eles se tornem obsoletos

p.b: Alemanha: Show "Practical Linux" em 11 de outubro em Gießen

body.p: Benjamin Judas, também conhecido como Beejay, um Gentooísta vivendo a apenas meia hora do local da conferência, anunciou a participação do Gentoo no Dia Prático Linux deste ano, um evento anual na Fachhochschule Gießen (Universida de Ciências Aplicadas), localizada a 80km ao norte de Frankfurt/Main. Beejay irá dar uma apresentação durante a sessão principal, e uma tenda do Gentoo será, certamente, ocupada pelos suspeitos usuais. Uma carga de LiveCDs frequinhos é dita estar a caminho para venda no show. Conte aos outros jovens que você esta indo no tópico correspondente (em alemão).

p.b: Germany: "Practical Linux" Show on 11 October in Gie?en

body.p: Benjamin Judas, aka Beejay, a Gentooist living a mere half hour from the conference venue, has announced Gentoo's participation in this year's Practical Linux Day, an annual event at the Fachhochschule Gie?en (University of Applied Science), located about 80 km north of Frankfurt/Main. Beejay will give a presentation during the main session, and a Gentoo booth will undoubtedly be manned by the usual suspects. A shipment of freshly minted LiveCD is rumoured to be on its way for sale at the show. Tell the other lads you're coming at at the corresponding forum thread (in German).

Usuários de banda larga não deveriam ter toda a diversão. Um membro da lista gentoo-user queria saber quais dicas e truques estavam disponíveis para usuários dial-up, e algumas muito boas foram postadas. Leia aqui.

Total packages: 6026

The Gentoo community uses Bugzilla (bugs.gentoo.org) to record and track bugs, notifications, suggestions and other interactions with the development team. Between 05 September 2003 and 11 September 2003, activity on the site has resulted in:

ul.li: 437 new bugs during this period
295 bugs closed or resolved during this period
8 previously closed bugs were reopened this period

body.p: Of the 3864 currently open bugs: 94 are labeled 'blocker', 200 are labeled 'critical', and 285 are labeled 'major'.
The developers and teams who have closed the most bugs during this period are:

ul.li: Gentoo Release Team, with 19 closed bugs
Mirror Admins, with 16 closed bugs
Gentoo Games, with 16 closed bugs
Seemant Kulleen, with 13 closed bugs

body.p: An introduction to sudo

This week's tip demonstrates some common uses of sudo which allows normal users to run commands with elevated privileges. This week we look at using sudo to view log files and handle basic user administration.

The first thing to do is set up the /etc/sudoers file which controls all the privileges handled by sudo. Instead of editing this file directly, use the visudo command. For a full list of configuration options, see the sudoers man page (man 5 sudoers).
This file is just an example and demonstrates how to create command and user aliases.
body.pre:
# sudoers file. # # This file MUST be edited with the 'visudo' command as root. # # See the sudoers man page for the details on how to write a sudoers file. #
# User alias specification User_Alias HELPDESK = jfox, helpdesk User_Alias SYSADMINS = david, jc
# Cmnd alias specification # Create aliases for all commands used in viewing files Cmnd_Alias VIEW = /bin/cat, /bin/grep, /bin/more, /usr/bin/head, \ /usr/bin/tail, /usr/bin/less
# commands for user administration Cmnd_Alias USERADMIN = /usr/sbin/useradd, /usr/sbin/userdel, \ /usr/sbin/usermod
# User privilege specification # Allow SYSADMINS to run any command as any user SYSADMINS ALL = ALL
# Allow users in HELPDESK to use the user administration commands and # to use the VIEW commands without a password HELPDESK ALL = USERADMIN, NOPASSWD:VIEW
# Allow users in the %users group to use the VIEW commands %users ALL = VIEW
body.p: Now that your /etc/sudoers file has been created, you can issue commands using sudo command.
body.pre:
Viewing /var/log/critical/current as the helpdesk user helpdesk@mybox% sudo tail /var/log/critical/current
Adding a new user as the user jfox jfox@mybox% sudo useradd marcus Password: password for jfox
body.p: While this is no means comprehensive, this should introduce you to some of the many possibilities of sudo. For more examples and options see the man pages or the web page at http://www.courtesan.com/sudo/.
